The **Magic 8-Ball** is an [artifact](/wiki/Artifact "Artifact") that appears in [EvilHack](/wiki/EvilHack "EvilHack"). It is [unaligned](/wiki/Unaligned "Unaligned"), and its [base item](/wiki/Base_item "Base item") is an [eight ball](/wiki/Eight_ball "Eight ball").

[ ]

## Contents

- [1 Generation](#Generation)
- [2 Description](#Description)
- [3 Strategy](#Strategy)
- [4 Origin](#Origin)
- [5 Encyclopedia entry](#Encyclopedia_entry)

## Generation

The Magic 8-Ball cannot be [wished](/wiki/Wish "Wish") for, and reverts to its base item if left in [bones](/wiki/Bones "Bones").

[The Oracle](/wiki/Oracle_\(monster\) "Oracle (monster)") is always generated with the Magic 8-Ball during the creation of [her level](/wiki/Oracle_\(monster\) "Oracle (monster)").

## Description

The Magic 8-Ball is implied to be the source of the Oracle's knowledge. It grants [warning](/wiki/Warning "Warning") while carried, and can be [applied](/wiki/Applied "Applied") to divulge a random [rumor](/wiki/Rumor "Rumor") - the rumor will be true or false based on the artifact's [beatitude](/wiki/Beatitude "Beatitude"): true if blessed, false if cursed, and an equal probability of each if uncursed. Additionally, there is a 1⁄100,000 chance that applying the blessed Magic 8-Ball will grant the user a [wish](/wiki/Wish "Wish"), which causes it to disappear afterward.

[Reading](/wiki/Read "Read") the Magic 8-Ball randomly generates one of twenty responses that have no effect.

## Strategy

The Magic 8-Ball is highly sought after as a source of slotless warning, which can be used to spot lethal hostile monsters such as [beholders](/wiki/Beholder_\(EvilHack\) "Beholder (EvilHack)"), [gelatinous cubes](/wiki/Gelatinous_cube "Gelatinous cube"), [water elementals](/wiki/Water_elemental "Water elemental"), and the various [zombies](/wiki/Zombie_\(EvilHack\) "Zombie (EvilHack)") - many of the listed monsters and others considered especially dangerous cannot be seen with [telepathy](/wiki/Telepathy "Telepathy").

Many players consider it worth killing the Oracle for, either directly or through the use of a [pet](/wiki/Pet "Pet"): while even some of the strongest pets will struggle to directly withstand the Oracle's wrath and kill her without dying in the process, directly angering the Oracle means contending with her [spellcasting](/wiki/Monster_spell "Monster spell") abilities and [magic missile](/wiki/Magic_missile "Magic missile") passive, as well as her gaining mobility along with [covetous](/wiki/Covetous "Covetous") warping and the ability to break [boulders](/wiki/Boulder "Boulder") obstructing her path.

## Origin

[![Wikipedia](/images/thumb/f/f8/Fair-use-wikipedia-logo.png/50px-Fair-use-wikipedia-logo.png)](/wiki/File:Fair-use-wikipedia-logo.png "Wikipedia")

[Wikipedia](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Main_Page "wikipedia:Main Page") has an article about:

***[Magic 8-Ball](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Magic_8-Ball "wikipedia:Magic 8-Ball")***

A Magic 8-Ball is a plastic sphere made to look like an oversized billiards eight-ball, used for fortune-telling or seeking advice. It was invented in 1946 by Albert C. Carter and Abe Bookman, and is currently manufactured by Mattel - originally designed as a paperweight, it has since become a popular office toy and children's toy. The Magic 8-Ball contains a blue twenty-sided die with white letters in a pool of blue liquid; the user asks a yes–no question to the ball, then turns it over to reveal an answer in a window on the ball.

In fiction, the Magic 8-Ball is often used for humor, with it giving very accurate, very inaccurate, or otherwise statistically improbable answers. The standard Magic 8-Ball has 20 possible responses when read: 10 affirmative answers, 5 non-committal answers, and 5 negative answers. The artifact in EvilHack uses these standard responses when read, and one of them is used as the [encyclopedia](/wiki/Encyclopedia "Encyclopedia") entry.
